title-group.article-title: The Impact of Exponential Growth Variables on Regression Models of the Market–Accounting Relation

author-notes.corresp: Roger J. Willett, University of Tasmania, Private Bag 86, Sandy Bay, Hobart, Tasmania 7001, Australia. Email: roger.willett@utas.edu.au

abstract.p: Exponential growth of market value, book value, and earnings is a basic characteristic of many firms. We propose a simple theory linking market value to a multiplicative relation of accounting variables and a lognormal error term, when model variables exhibit this characteristic. Implications for the interpretation of estimated coefficients in commonly used additive linear models of the market–accounting relation in both levels and returns are discussed. We test the theory using a selected panel of 30 of some of the largest long-lived U.S. firms over a 50-year period. Annual cross-section and firm-specific dynamic models of market regressed on accounting values are estimated in levels. Multiplicative models of levels data produce markedly improved statistical specifications compared with additive forms. Lags are also shown to be necessary to produce well-specified dynamic models. A multiplicative returns model based on error correction principles is derived from the multiplicative levels model providing for a straightforward interpretation of the magnitude of coefficients relating market to accounting values. Estimates from deflated returns models are reinterpreted in the light of these results as approximations to estimates derived from multiplicative levels models.

body.p: This article assesses the implications of exponential growth in variables used in regression analysis of the market–accounting relation in capital market research (CMR). Additive model specifications commonly used are compared with multiplicative specifications.1 It is argued that multiplicative specifications provide an explanation of the relationship between accounting numbers and market value for an important class of large, long-lived U.S. firms more consistent with fundamental economic theory and empirical evidence.

A theory supporting multiplicative specifications, including lagged market and accounting variables and lognormal errors, when exponential growth variables are modeled is described. If such models are better descriptions of sample data than the additive models usually assumed in the literature, there are several implications. In levels models, similar to those used by Barth, Beaver, and Landsman (1998), coefficient estimates are biased and inconsistent. Despite this, they frequently produce highly significant t and R2 statistics. If the multiplicative levels form is common to the firms in the sample and reflects a long-run relationship between market and accounting values, well-specified returns regressions that are a cross-sectional re-expression of a multiplicative error correction model can be formulated, thus avoiding such estimation problems.

To test the theory, a selected sample of panel data for 30 long-lived firms over a 50-year period is used to estimate additive cross-sectional and dynamic models of the levels relationship between accounting and market values. These are shown to be statistically misspecified. As predicted by the theory, however, specification is markedly improved by a multiplicative formulation of these models with lagged variables. Furthermore, we show how the coefficients of returns models that deflate additive levels models by opening market values, such as in Easton and Harris (1991), can be reinterpreted as estimated partial elasticities, not per unit changes in the variables.

A particular feature of the models advocated in this article is the inclusion of lagged market value as an explanatory variable. Coefficients on this variable cannot be reliably estimated by standard cross-section means, and they are rarely a component in cross-section analysis of levels in CMR. Yet, lagged market values usually have very significant explanatory power for current market value, because their time series nearly always behave as a random walk. Returns models based on an additive levels relationship indirectly introduce lagged market value through the deflation process. However, this imposes an implicit assumption that the coefficient on this variable is 1. This assumption prevents deflated returns models from saying anything significant about the different short- and long-run effects of accounting numbers on market values. The error correction returns models estimated in the article do allow this. Furthermore, because the multiplicative returns model is derived from its levels counterpart without altering the distributional characteristics of the error term, the coefficient estimates of the returns model can be explicitly derived from those of the levels model, making their interpretation easier.

Our aim in this article is not to generalize parameter estimates to large sets of firms. Our sample is non-random and selected for a purpose. The purpose is to demonstrate that valid and reliable average parameter estimates of the market–accounting relation can be achieved for quite small samples of firms, provided that the statistical model used to produce the estimates is well specified in the sense that the assumptions underlying the model can be shown to be correct. The emphasis is on accurately estimating the parameters of interest for a sample of firms, so that these can be compared with those derived from other firm samples, for policy making and other reasons. Incorrect statistical specification of models leads to bias in parameter estimation, even when samples are random and large. Thus, large sample sizes, as illustrated later in this article, may produce highly significant but biased estimates, leading to overconfidence in wrong coefficient magnitudes.

The following section (a) reviews some prior research relevant to the issues outlined above, (b) describes the economic reasoning underlying the theory behind the multiplicative model, and (c) discusses its implications for the interpretation of coefficients derived from additive models. The “Data and Method” section explains the data sources and methods used to analyze the sample data. The “Empirical Evidence” section tests the theory, comparing cross-section and time-series sample estimates and specification statistics for additive and multiplicative models. The “Conclusion” section summarizes the findings.

sec.title: Related Prior Research, Theory, and Implications
Prior Research
sec.p: This article follows in the dividend discounting, economic rationality tradition of fundamentals analysis in CMR (Kothari, 2001; Richardson & Tinaikar, 2004) but questions the specification of the most common statistical models that have been used to test theory and inform the interpretation of coefficient estimates. In this regard, it complements and echoes the more recent concerns expressed in papers such as Petersen (2009) on the use of panel analysis in the presence of certain types of residual behavior and Lennox, Francis, and Wang (2012) on the need to report sensitivity and robustness tests of statistical models used in accounting research.

In the now vast literature using cross-section regression models of the type discussed in this article, two are particularly relevant as a point of comparison for the alternative multiplicative formulation we propose. Barth et al. (1998) approach the problem of how to obtain meaningful and reliable estimates of the relationship between “levels” of market and accounting values by formulating a type of model, commonly seen in the CMR literature, which is here referred to as an “additive linear” model. Easton and Harris (1991) use “returns” formulations, usually interpreted as “deflated” additive levels model derived by dividing its variables by opening market value. The returns formulation is either used for substantive reasons (i.e., the interest is in market returns rather than market values) or in an attempt to address a perceived problem with “scale” in levels regressions (as recommended by Christie, 1987).2
Generic descriptions of models of the type used in the Barth and Easton papers cited above are, respectively,
and

M
i , t

i

A

is a vector of accounting and other firm
i
-specific variables at
t
; the estimates of the parameters
k
,
b
,
k ′
, and
b ′
are vectors of constant coefficients; and
u t
and
w t
are white noise error terms. In cross-section applications, the “true” parameters may vary with
t
. In time-series models, the parameters may vary with
i
. Usually, one or both of these assumptions underpin inference, though it may be admitted that their failure can lead to inaccuracies in estimation (e.g., the scale arguments contained in Barth & Clinch, 2009; Barth & Kallapur, 1996; Easton & Sommers, 2003). Many variants of these regressions are used in cross-section and time-series analyses, including forms of Equation 1 regressing returns rather than market value (e.g., Chen & Zhang, 2007; Fama & French, 1992; Kothari & Shanken, 1997). Moreover, dividends are frequently used to adjust either the right-hand side or the left-hand side or both sides of Equation 2, for example, in Easton and Harris (1991).

Theoretical approaches to fundamentals attempt to derive, from underlying economic assumptions, a precise form for the valuation relationship expected to be observed between accounting numbers and market value. Among these, Ohlson (1995) suggests net book value and abnormal returns as the key components in the vector
A
i , t
. Penman and Yehuda (2009) argue that a simple market-equals-book-value model can explain returns. Burgstahler and Dichev (1997) and more generally Ashton, Cooke, Tippett, and Wang (2004) develop theories that imply nonlinear forms for the relationship between accounting numbers and market value. Most tests of models such as these published to date assume that the error term enters additively, with normality of the error term also assumed to allow inferences to be made about the statistical significance of model coefficients.

Using this approach to establish which model is descriptively best has proved difficult. Tests of Ohlson’s (1995) model in its additive form tend to be inconclusive or negative (e.g., Dechow, Hutton, & Sloan, 1999; Morel, 2003; Myers, 1999). Some studies using additive models evidence variation in estimated coefficient values and inferential statistics over time in large annual cross sections of data. This has been taken to imply that parameters in the underlying data generation processes (DGPs) vary over time, adducing an economic interpretation to the variation in magnitudes and significance of book value and earnings coefficients (e.g., Barth et al., 1998; Collins, Maydew, & Weiss, 1997; Francis & Schipper, 1999; Ryan & Zarowin, 2003). This makes it important to use correctly specified models for estimation because incorrect specification can cause estimates to vary misleadingly between samples, even if the underlying parameters are stable (Hendry, 1995).

Excluding the matter of “scale” discussed below, the magnitudes of estimated parameter coefficients are less debated than are changes in relative magnitudes over time, level of significance, and expected signs (e.g., Chen & Zhang, 2007). This avoids dealing with the central issue of fundamentals, because accurate estimation of the magnitude of the coefficients in levels and returns models is what is needed to understand the origin of firm value. Studies such as Kothari and Shanken (1997) and Barth et al. (1998) provide descriptive statistics for sample averages of relevant ratios (e.g., the market-to-book ratio) but the sense of the magnitude of estimated coefficients relative to the descriptive ratios is not extensively analyzed, especially in the context of returns regressions.

The recent debate about “scale” is motivated, in part, by the perception it causes difficulties in interpreting the magnitudes of coefficient estimates (Barth & Clinch, 2009; Barth & Kallapur, 1996; Easton & Sommers, 2003). In this debate, scale does not refer, as is usual in statistical contexts, to the units of measurement used for model variables. Instead it refers to the relative magnitudes of regressor variables and their variability, in the belief that these variations cause bias and inconsistency3 in cross-section estimation. Barth and Clinch (2009) believe that the problem can be addressed by searching for missing variables that eliminate the underlying factor that scales model regressors. Easton and Sommers (2003) consider that scale is best measured by market value and that using the market value as a deflator eliminates scale by definition.

Differences in the relative sizes and variability of regressor variables cannot, in themselves, cause coefficient bias in well-specified statistical models. Variation is needed to obtain precision in coefficient estimates. Variation in size can appear to cause bias and inconsistency in certain statistical models if size is correlated with heterogeneous parameter magnitudes in the underlying DGP. However, econometric research shows that Equations 1 and 2 are robust to such parameter heterogeneity (e.g., Pesaran & Smith, 1995). If bias and inconsistency occur in estimating the coefficients in either Equation 1 or 2 or both, it must therefore be due to other sources of model misspecification.

An example of why misspecification of some sort is suspected in regression models of the market–accounting relation is the results reported in Easton and Harris (1991) and Easton and Sommers (2003). The problem lies in the low magnitude of the earnings response coefficient in deflated returns models in which earnings is the sole explanatory variable. Pooled estimates and average cross-section estimates of parameters in both papers are close to zero for the intercept and close to one for the earnings response coefficient. Yet, as the latter paper shows and as is generally observed, the multiplier on earnings in a simple one-variable, market-value-levels regression of the type described by Equation 1 is an order of magnitude greater. If deflated returns models are derived from an underlying “true” linear levels relationship of the form of Equation 1 by dividing its sole variable by lagged market value, in large samples, we would expect the coefficient on the earnings term to be of a similar order of magnitude following the deflation process, assuming the assumptions of the classical linear model are satisfied.4 This makes it natural to question the statistical specification of Equation 1, a point about which most papers using this model are silent.

The most commonly mentioned possible causes of misspecification cited in the CMR literature are correlated omitted variables, heteroskedasticity, influential variables, outliers, and a “scale effect” (e.g., Barth & Clinch, 2009; Barth et al., 1998; Easton & Sommers, 2003; Kothari & Shanken, 1997, 2003). The acceptance of correlated omitted variables, as being a key reason for misspecification, is one of the main reasons researchers perform sensitivity tests on coefficient estimates by including and excluding different variables in their models. Heteroskedasticity is usually dealt with by tests and adjustments, such as those recommended by White (1980), for example Barth and Kallapur (1996). Influential variables and outliers are a particular feature of deflated models due to the distributional properties of ratios. The former may be identified by using studentized residuals (Easton & Sommers, 2003). Outliers can be treated by Winsorization (e.g., Kothari & Shanken, 1997).

Attempting to cure misspecification in the ways just described, can, especially if done piecemeal and without consideration for the possible effect on the distributional properties of model diagnostics, obscure true relationships and lead to a proliferation of different explanations that change with each new sample of data. R2 can be particularly misleading (Brown, Lo, & Lys, 1999). Heteroskedasticity may be apparent, rather than real, caused by substantive misspecification in the functional form of a model.5 Superficially dealing with heteroskedasticity by using adjusted t-values may encourage accepting an estimate as statistically significant when it is, in fact, not an estimate of the parameter of interest at all. Eliminating influential variables and outliers supposes that the extreme observations are unrepresentative of the population of interest, which may result in throwing out informative data. Why, for instance, might researchers dispose of observations as outliers when the data are transformed by deflation, when prior to the transformation they are retained in a model testing a similar hypothesis?

Specification tests of models should be comprehensive, covering as many assumptions of the maintained regression model as possible. This means testing for normality of residuals, as well as heteroskedasticity, and performing checks on functional form. In time-series modeling, serial correlation of residuals and cointegration between the market and accounting variables are also crucial points to check. We adopt this comprehensive approach to testing the specification of the levels model in Equation 1 and its counterpart multiplicative model. The results are reported in the “Empirical Evidence” section, after a more detailed account of the statistical methods we use. Next, we provide a theory to explain why we believe multiplicative models form the basis for a more accurate description of the relationship between accounting numbers and market value than do additive models.

sec.title: Theory
sec.p: It is questionable if the assumption of an additive linear regression model is reasonable in the context of the pricing of financial securities. Most empirical and theoretical evidence suggests that, as security prices increase, their variance increases, and that their distribution is approximated by, for example, the lognormal (e.g., Black & Scholes, 1973). Consequently, it is natural to ask what part accounting information might play in explaining market values that have such characteristics.

The approach we take to answering this question is based on market value being the aggregate of two causes: accounting effects in which there are possibly short- as well as long-run elements, and a short-run trading effect on the volatility of market value reflecting other information impacting on the demand and supply of shares in the stock market. As in fundamental economic theory, we assume that in the long run, financial market returns equate to underlying real accounting returns (Miller & Modigliani, 1961). Consequently, the long-run effects of our model are captured in the accounting component and the non-accounting, short-run effects are centered on zero.

A simple functional form for the long-run relationship between accounting numbers and market value of the ith firm in period
t

The long-run market–book relationship in Equations 3 and 4 gives a straightforward interpretation of the model variables as combining multiplicatively, with an error term that behaves “intensively” magnified by scale. The form is the same as the Cobb–Douglas production function in economics (Cobb & Douglas, 1928). If it is well specified and the data are positive, the model can be estimated by OLS by taking logs of the variables in the model, as detailed in the following section. Log transformations are used routinely in specific and ad hoc contexts to achieve particular outcomes in CMR (e.g., to make a variable appear more Gaussian) but the simple expedient of transforming all variables to logs is not common.6 When a log model is used, the interpretation of the estimated parameters is that they are elasticities, measures of the proportionate rate of change of the regressand due to a proportionate rate of change in the regressors.

Time delays in the disclosure of accounting information increase the likelihood that the presumed long-run effect of accounting on market values, represented by the coefficient estimates
k
i , t
and
β
i , j , t
in Equation 4, may omit the impact of some short-run effects. If such is the case, lags on the model variables may be required to provide the stationary properties necessary for valid assessment of long- and short-run effects. A great deal of empirical evidence shows that relationships between suitably transformed time series of data in economics are often statistically well specified by an autoregressive distributed lag (Hendry, Pagan, & Sargan, 1984). This suggests that the relationship between accounting numbers and market value for the ith firm should in the first instance be checked for lags, that is, be specified as

Here, the terms are as in Equation 4 and
α
i , t − 1
is an autoregressive coefficient. For dynamic stability of Equation 5, the value of this coefficient must lie between 0 and 1. A value close to 1 means that market value, conditional upon accounting values, is close to a pure random walk. In this case, the short-run impact of the accounting variables is minimal and they affect market values only slowly over time. A value close to 0 means that accounting values play a more important role in determining market values. It is assumed, for expositional purposes and for reasons of applicability to the present case, that single lags on the market and accounting variables are sufficient to produce a white noise error term.

sec.title: Implications for Inference and Interpretation of Regression Model Estimates
sec.p:
In the cross section, estimating the slope coefficient in Equation 1 does not provide an estimate of the accounting response coefficient, if Equation 5 is the correct common form of the firm DGPs. In that case, estimates of the accounting “response coefficients,” the parameter
b
in Equation 1, are biased and inconsistent. This is because that
b
is not the parameter of interest, a point that has policy as well as theoretical implications.

If the processes that generate sample data are better statistically approximated by a multiplicative model, the effect on estimates of coefficients on the accounting variables can be illustrated analytically as follows. Assume that data are generated by the single variable multiplicative process,

where the variables are as previously defined,
κ
is a scaling parameter and
ω t
is lognormal, LN(0,1). Then the expected OLS estimate of the slope or response coefficient derived from a model incorrectly using Equation 1 is

where

Thus, if
κ
is actually equal to 3, for example, wrongly using Equation 1 to estimate
b
^
results in an estimate of the response coefficient of approximately 4.95. This bias is not alleviated by increasing the sample size.

The consequences of such misspecification for inference and for why large samples might produce misleading confidence in incorrect results are illustrated in the results of a computational experiment mirroring the situation described above. Figure 1 shows histograms from a Monte Carlo simulation experiment in which data are generated from the distributions with the parameters described in Table 1. The sampling distributions for the coefficients and inferential statistics of the incorrectly specified linear additive model are highly skewed and located near to 5 for the distribution of possible slope values.

caption.p: Note. Histograms of coefficients, t-statistics, and R2 from Monte Carlo simulation. Left half: Data based on 1,000 replications for 30 firms. Right half: Data based on 10,000 replications for 300 firms.

Experiment illustrating the effect on OLS coefficient estimates and inferential statistics of modeling 30 and 300 firms each, using a Monte Carlo simulation with 1,000 and 10,000 replications, respectively, a DGP that is multiplicative of the Form

fn.p: Note. The SD given is the between-sample SD. We give the conclusion in the table. Conclusion: Estimating a DGP that is multiplicative in regressors and error term by a simple linear additive model leads to biased coefficient estimates that fluctuate widely between samples. Although larger sample sizes reduce the degree of fluctuation, they do not eliminate the bias in the estimates leading to the incorrect estimate appearing to be increasingly statistically significant as the sample size grows. SD = Standard deviation; OLS = Ordinary least squares; DGP = Data generation process.

sec.p: Despite the misleading conclusions that might be drawn from estimating using Equation 1 when the process generating the data has a multiplicative form, the t-statistic on the slope coefficient in the incorrect model is significant at least at the 5% level in samples of 30 firms approximately 35% of the time. In samples of 300 firms, the slope coefficient continues to remain significant at about the same level. The between-sample variation in the inferential statistics diminishes with increased sample size but is large, even in sample sizes of 300 firms, producing the impression of unstable coefficients. The average sample value of the t-statistic for the incorrectly specified model depends on the particular values of the parameters of the underlying DGP and does not diminish with increasing sample size, as would usually happen with a correctly specified model. Under these circumstances, the risk of being wrongly convinced that an incorrect model is correct increases with the size of the sample. If a model is misspecified, large randomly selected sample sizes are not beneficial.

Later, in the “Empirical Evidence” section, we test hypotheses about the outcome of specification tests of the additive linear and multiplicative levels models. We also estimate and interpret coefficients produced by the counterpart deflated and error correction returns models derived from the levels models. The empirical hypotheses to be tested are summarized as follows:

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1: Cross-section and dynamic additive linear models in levels, as represented in Equation 1, estimated on samples of large, long-lived U.S. firms are misspecified.
Hypothesis 2: Cross-section and dynamic multiplicative models in levels, as represented in Equation 5, estimated on samples of large, long-lived U.S. firms are not misspecified.

sec.p: The data and method we use to test these hypotheses are discussed in the following section.

sec.title: Data and Method
sec.p: This section of the article describes the data and statistical methods used to estimate and test the specification of the cross-section and dynamic regression models of the levels relation between accounting numbers and market value reported in the “Empirical Evidence” section. The sample data are selected, non-randomly, from Compustat files to include firms that approximate the long-lived firms assumed in the theory described in the previous section. All have December 31 financial year ends. At the time the sample was first obtained (2001), these were all the firms from the Standard and Poor’s (S&P) 500 that had historical data over the 50-year period with no missing values. Given that they all existed over the 50-year period, we consider them to be “survivors”. The identity of the 30 firms in the sample is evident from the tables later in the article (see Table 5).

The three variables
M t
,
B t
, and
E t
used in the models are as observed at the balance sheet date of December 31. Market value
M t
is calculated as the common share price at the financial year end multiplied by the number of outstanding shares at the same date. These are raw data, unadjusted for splits, that is, the values that would have been observed in the share markets at December 31 in each year. Reported book value of net assets
B t
is the “Common Equity” data field in Compustat. Reported accounting earnings
E t
is Compustat’s “Net Income” variable. The accounting variables are as reported in the annual balance sheet date of December 31. The simplicity of the data fields makes it easy to replicate the estimates reported in this article. More specific information about the sources of data is given in Table 2.

caption.p: Definitions and sources of data used in empirical models.

tr.td: Earnings, dividends, and book value of net assets
As defined by Compustat annual data item numbers A172, A21, and A60, respectively. Sources: Compustat tapes—1955-1998; Mergent Online 1999-2002; Company website 2005.
Defined as share price at fiscal year end (A199) multiplied by the number of shares outstanding. Sources: Compustat 1955-1998; Datastream 1999-2002; Company website 2005.

sec.p: Both cross-section and dynamic models use standard OLS estimation, inferential and diagnostic techniques. A summary description of the Augmented Dickey Fuller (ADF) tests for unit roots in the dynamic models and of the lesser known misspecification tests is contained in Table 3.

caption.p: Statistical tests for misspecification and unit roots.

tr.td: Test null of correct specification against alternative that squares of estimates of the dependent have been omitted (as per Hendry & Doornik, 2001, p. 263).

Test null of unconditional heteroskedasticity against alternative that the variance of the error process depends on squares of the regressors as well as the regressors themselves (Hendry & Doornik, 2001, p. 262).
F-test form for unconditional autocorrelation. Null hypothesis is of no autocorrelation of residuals (Hendry & Doornik, 2001, p. 260).
Chi-square test. Null hypothesis is normality of residuals (Hendry & Doornik, 2001, p. 261).
ADF tests with constant. Null is non-stationarity (Hendry & Doornik, 2001, pp. 230-231).

fn.p: Note. ADF = Augmented Dickey Fuller.

sec.p: The multiplicative models of market value in Equation 5 can be estimated directly using nonlinear techniques or with OLS by taking logs of the variables. The latter approach is used because it provides easy access to well-tried estimation methods and standard inferential and specification tests. This requires, however, that the data points are positive. Out of the 1,500 data points from the entire period of analysis, there are 5 and 60 instances of negative book values and earnings, respectively. In such cases, the log values corresponding to these negative values are set to equal −10.
With positive data, Equation 5 is transformed in logs to

If Equation 10 is statistically well specified, OLS in a dynamic regression produces consistent estimates of its parameters with a bias in the estimate of the autoregressive term reducing as the length of the sample period increases. Running the “static” regression, that is, Equation 10 over time without any lagged variables, gives consistent OLS estimates of its implied long-run parameters. However, these estimates are biased at finite sample lengths. Consequently, it is safer to include lagged variables in the dynamic specification of the relationship between accounting numbers and market value than to exclude them.

The firm parameter variation expected in theory and noted in the empirical literature makes it unwise to rely on OLS estimates of coefficients in cross-section models of Equation 10. Forms of panel analysis are required in this case. In models with random parameters, panel estimation can be based on simulated maximum likelihood (e.g., see Greene, 2008). Alternatively, OLS can be used in individual firm modeling and the coefficient estimates explicitly averaged across the firm sample, as recommended by Pesaran and Smith (1995). This is the approach used later to estimate the coefficients in Equation 10 and is justified by the long length of our panel data. However, as noted earlier, ordinary cross-section OLS estimates of the long run in the form of Equation 1 are robust to the effect of parameter heterogeneity and so can form the basis of reliable inference, if the model is otherwise well specified (Pesaran & Smith, 1995).

sec.title: Empirical Evidence
sec.p: This section examines the sample data to test the hypotheses stated at the end of “Related Prior Research, Theory, and Implications” section. We first consider the visual patterns in the data to demonstrate that these are consistent with the assumptions of the theory described in that section. Then we report the results of diagnostic tests of the additive and multiplicative levels models of the relationship between accounting numbers and market value showing the former are misspecified and the latter are not. Finally, we estimate parameters for the error correction returns model implied by the multiplicative levels model. The interpretation of the magnitude of the parameters thus produced is explained and used to reinterpret the magnitude of coefficients in deflated earnings returns models reported in previous research.

Figure 2 provides views of time-series patterns the sample averages, across the 30 firms, of market value, net book value, and earnings. Also shown is the geometric mean of book and earnings displaying clear evidence of an exponential growth pattern over the 50-year sample period (Figure 2, left). In Figure 2 (right), we also exhibit corresponding histograms of the relative frequency distributions. Their patterns show a visual resemblance to lognormal distributions.

caption.p: Scatter and relative frequency plots of 30 firms averaged sample data.

Note. Left: Growth patterns of net book value, earnings, the geometric mean of net book value and earnings, and market value for the period from 1955 to 2004. Given are also results from exponential, y = a•exp(bx), and linear, y = a+bx, fits to the data, for the latter only the net book value fit is shown. Right: Corresponding relative frequency distributions of dollar amounts using eight intervals each. Given are also results from logarithmic, y = a+b•ln(x), fits to the data.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the cross-section relationships between market value and three sets of accounting values based on time averaged data for each individual firm. The cross-section relationship between market value and the accounting variables is approximately linear, whether or not the variables are transformed to logs. The impact of growth in the DGP of these variables is seen in the cross section by apparent heteroskedasticity in the scatter plots of market value with the accounting regressors (Figure 3, top row).

caption.p: Cross-section scatter plots in raw data and logs of time averaged sample data over the estimation period 1955 to 1994.

Note. The larger R2 values from linear fitting and visual inspection favor the logarithmic scale for ordinary least squares (OLS) estimation. Also visible is the good correspondence between earnings and market value, an indication as to which accounting variable eventually transpires most frequently in the top-down variable elimination process.

sec.p: The patterns in the average data are representative of the individual series, whether this is over time by individual firms or in the cross section by year across firms. Time averaging reduces the impact of heteroskedasticity in the cross section.7 The appearance of heteroskedasticity in the untransformed numbers and its disappearance when they are logged is more obvious in the annual data. This is true of virtually all of the 50 years in the sample.

Figure 4 displays histograms of the raw and log data, averaged for each firm across time, for each of the variables. The raw data are more skewed and the log transform gives a more normal shape to them.

caption.p: Histograms of raw and logged time averaged sample data over the estimation period 1955 to 1994.
Note. Details of fits are also displayed: for the raw data, we used linear logarithmic forms, and for the logged data, the normal distribution.

sec.p: Barth et al. (1998) model “levels” relationships between market and accounting values as follows:

M
i , t
is market value and
B
i , t
the book value of net assets of firm
i
at time
t
,
E
i , t
is annual earnings of firm
i
during the period ending with
t
, and
ε
t
is a white noise error term. The result of using this model to estimate coefficients is shown in Table 4, where it is applied in the cross section to the 30 firms in our sample in each of the 50 years.

caption.p: Cross-section models, estimated using equation 11, for 30 firms based on yearly data from 1955 to 2004.

fn.p: Note. Specification tests (see Table 3) indicate statistical significance at the 1% level (**) and 5% level (*).

sec.p: In many years, the coefficients test as being statistically significant, sometimes highly so. The R2 statistics are invariably high, usually above 70% and often more than 80%. However, the coefficient estimates fluctuate from year to year, often changing sign. Such instability in coefficient estimates could be an indication of a misspecified model rather than being due to underlying systematic factors. The diagnostic statistics in the last three columns of Table 4 confirm that, as a model of the data, Equation 11 is statistically misspecified.

Estimating Equation 11 as individual firm
i
time series (dynamic approach) produces the same statistical indications of misspecification (see Table 5). Thus, based on the frequency of flagging significance in the specification tests, Hypothesis 1 cannot be rejected.

caption.p: Dynamic models, estimated using equation 11, for 30 firms based on data from 1955 to 1994.

fn.p: Note. Compare Table 3 for details on specification tests. Statistical significance levels given are at the 1% level (**) and 5% level (*).

sec.p: Running Equation 11 in logs,

that is, implying a multiplicative process, produces the results shown in Table 6. Now the coefficients show a more stable and consistent pattern, summing to approximate unity in each year. Book values increase from negative to positive values during the sample period and the coefficient on earnings falls from values mostly in excess of 1 until 1980 to mostly small positive values after 1990. Earnings are more often statistically significant in the early years, and book values in the later years, but that feature is affected by the closeness of the coefficients to 0 in different years. The diagnostic tests flag misspecification in the model no more than might be expected by chance at the 5% level.

caption.p: Cross-section models, estimated using Equation 12, for 30 firms based on yearly data from 1955 to 2004.

fn.p: Note. Specification tests (see Table 3) indicate statistical significance at the 1% level (**) and 5% level (*).

sec.p: Dynamic regressions using the log-form of Equation 11 produce specification statistics that appear to show a well-specified model. However, in this case, an additional test for non-stationarity of the residuals is required to be confident that the long-run relationship between the market and accounting variables is not spurious (e.g., see Greene, 2008). ADF tests indicate non-stationarity in 21 of the 30 firm models (see Table 7, last column). Adding a single lag for each variable to Equation 12,

caption.p: Dynamic models, estimated using Equation 13, for 30 firms using data from 1955 to 1994.

fn.p: Note. NSWL, that is, model is non-stationary unless lags are added. All models test stationary by ADF tests when lags are present. Statistical significance levels given are at the 1% level (**) and 5% level (*). NSWL = Non-stationary without lags; ADF = Augmented Dickey Fuller.

sec.p: including the dependent variable, cures the problem of nonstationarity. The resulting model is well specified and provides statistical evidence of a non-spurious, long-run relationship between the market and accounting values. Hypothesis 2 also, therefore, cannot be rejected.

Given that there are 60 occasions when the log of negative earnings is replaced by a near zero positive value, we check the robustness of the misspecification statistics in Tables 4 to 7 by comparing them with those produced by models in which book value is the only independent variable. In this case, the strategy of replacing log book value by −10 occurs only 5 times in the cross-section models and once in the time-series models due to the shorter estimation period used in the latter.8 However, the incidence of misspecification remains noticeably higher in the additive model, despite the introduction of a lag on book value (see Tables A1 and A2 in the appendix).9 Consequently, we conclude that the presence of negative earnings does not materially affect our conclusions regarding Hypotheses 1 and 2.

Cross-section methods cannot be used to estimate Equation 13 due to the presence of the autoregressive term
M
i , t − 1
. The estimation approach suggested by Pesaran and Smith (1995) is therefore used, in which individual time-series coefficient estimates are averaged across the sample firms.

When the accounting vector consists of the single variable earnings,
E
t
, taking logs of Equation 13 and estimating the coefficients over the sample period 1968 to 1986 used in Easton and Harris (1991) produces the following coefficient, standard error10 (in brackets) and R2 statistics,
This model is well specified by the statistical tests described in Table 3 and in its untransformed, multiplicative form, this model is represented as

The interpretation of the magnitudes of the coefficients outside the parentheses is as percentages. The coefficient of 0.43 shows that, for this sample of firms, market gross returns over the period 1968 to 1986 reflected 43% of the short-run proportional change in earnings in the previous period. The term in lagged earnings in the numerator within the second set of parentheses is the estimated long-run relation between market value and earnings. It represents expected long-run market value as a nonlinear function of capitalized earnings, the multiplier on earnings diminishing as earnings becomes larger. Market returns adjust by about a third (0.33) of the relative imbalance between the expected market value, that is,
E {
M
t − 1
^
} = 154 (
E
t − 1
)
0 . 57
, and actual market value in the previous year,
M
t − 1
. Imbalances thus took about 3 years to correct, on average, during the period 1968 to 1986, for this sample of firms.

In reviewing prior research in the “Related Prior Research, Theory, and Implications” section, we noted a problem in interpreting the magnitude of coefficient estimates reported in empirical research using deflated returns models of the type in Equation 2 if they are assumed to be derived from the additive linear levels process described by Equation 1. Estimated coefficients, inferential and specification test statistics for the returns model used by Easton and Harris (1991), and for the model specified by Equation 2 estimated over the period 1968 to 1986 are shown in Table 8. The former estimates are of a similar order to those reported in Easton and Harris and the latter are not much different, showing that the change in the precise definition of the dependent returns variable has little effect on the magnitude of the coefficients. Pooling the data results in misspecified models whereas, on average, cross-section models pass the misspecification tests.

caption.p: Estimated cross-section coefficients from two deflated returns models and a partial elasticity model using data from 1968 to 1986.

sec.p: The most natural and probably the usual interpretation of the coefficient on earnings–price ratio in Equation 2 is that it is the percentage change in the response of the market return due to a unit change in the ratio. In view of the results in the previous section, therefore, it is of interest to consider whether there is a link between the deflated returns models and multiplicative levels models.

The interpretation of coefficients in double-log models as percentages suggests interpreting deflated returns models as approximations to a semilog, exponential model in which the coefficients are interpreted as partial elasticities, that is,

where
ε
t
is normally distributed. The justification for the approximation is the fact that
M
t
/
M
t − 1
≈ 1 + Δ ln (
M
t
)
when the former is close to 1. In Equation 16,
b ′
is a partial elasticity, the estimated percentage change in market value due to a unit change in the earnings–price ratio, which corresponds to the interpretation suggested above. The cross-section estimate of
b ′
in Equation 16 for the period 1968 to 1986 is reported in Table 8. While lower than those for the deflated models, it is of the same order of magnitude. The partial elasticity model is slightly better specified than the cross-section deflated models.
The model in Equation 16 is derived from a multiplicative levels model of the form,

where
ω
t
is again a lognormal error term. In this model, current market value is determined by applying a growth factor, estimated using the earnings–price ratio, to lagged market value. On this interpretation of deflated returns models, however, the estimated partial elasticity
b ′
mixes the short-run and long-run effects of changes in the earnings–price relation on market returns, unlike the estimates derived from Equation 14. Long-run responses are absorbed into the short-run estimate due to the implicit restriction placed upon the coefficient on
M
t
in Equation 17. Estimating the response of returns to the earnings–price relation based in Equation 16 is equivalent to assuming that the autoregressive coefficient on
M
t − 1
in Equation 17 is equal to 1. This linear restriction is statistically significant in nearly all the firms in our sample. Information about the long-run impact of earnings on returns is therefore lost by using estimates based on models derived from Equation 17.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In the presence of model variables that exhibit the characteristics of exponential growth over time, additive linear regression models of the market–accounting relation using levels data are likely to be misspecified. Levels models of this type of data with a multiplicative, log-normally distributed error term are more consistent with underlying theory and reported results. In our sample, they have a markedly improved statistical specification.

The empirical evidence from this and prior studies suggests that deflated returns models should not be thought of as being derived from misspecified, additive levels models. Instead, they are more consistently interpreted as approximate returns models derived from multiplicative, semilog (exponential) models. As such, the coefficients derived in deflated returns models in prior research can be validly interpreted as approximations to partial elasticities. In the case of earnings models, this means that the coefficient shows the percentage change in returns due to a unit change in the earnings–price ratio.

However, the loss of information about the long-run effect of accounting variables on market value suggests that deflated returns regressions defined as in Equation 2 are not the best way to make inferences about the transitory and permanent effects of earnings on returns. To analyze the short- and long-run effects of accounting variables, explicit recognition has to be given to lags in the data, especially the important impact of lagged market value. Short-run effects and the long-run relation between market and accounting value, as well as the length of the period over which market value adjusts for imbalances with accounting data, can be estimated using error correction forms of returns models and panel methods. An advantage of the returns model in Equation 2 compared with those based on Equation 13 is that losses do not have to be dealt with as special cases or by special transformations. It also has the advantage that it can be estimated reliably by cross-section methods. In contrast, Equation 13 usually cannot be reliably estimated by cross-section methods and must use some form of panel estimation. The data requirements necessary to estimate Equation 2 are minimal, whereas the data requirements needed to produce the estimated coefficients in Equation 13 with reasonable precision are high, due to the large number of parameters estimated. Panel methods used for estimating Equation 13 require long time series of data. Consequently, the choice between using Equations 2 and 13 involves a decision to trade the cost of more data with the benefit of more information. Whether the cost is worth the benefit depends on the purpose of estimation.

Applying the alternative modeling and estimating approach shows that large samples of firms are not necessarily needed to provide useful and reliable information about the market–accounting relation. If models of the market–accounting relation are statistically well specified reliable estimates of average coefficients on accounting values can be achieved with small samples of firms. If models are not statistically well specified, however, reliable estimation is not possible; no matter how large is the sample size.

fn.p: Author names are given in alphabetical order. This article is based on papers presented to the Australasian Meeting of the Econometric Society, Brisbane, University of Queensland, July 3-6, 2007; European Accounting Association 32nd Annual Congress in Tampere, Finland, May 12-15, 2009; Quantitative Accounting Research Symposium, June 5, 2009, University of Auckland Business School; Annual Workshop of the Methodological and Empirical Advances in Financial Analysis (MEAFA), University of Sydney, January 21-22, 2010; Seminar at the Leonard Stern School of Business, New York University, September 30, 2011; and Seminar at the University of Exeter, UK, October 21, 2011.

By additive (multiplicative) functional forms, we generally mean those in which the relationship between the untransformed independent variables and the error term is additive (multiplicative).
Easton and Sommers (2003) take the unusual step of deflating by closing market value, claiming that this reduces or eliminates bias in coefficient estimates in these models.
We use this term in the statistical sense, meaning that estimation bias continues to exist in large samples.

For example, assume
A
i , t
is earnings and
k
i , t
is zero. Substitution of Equation 1 into the ordinary least squares (OLS) formula for the slope coefficient in Equation 2 shows that
b
′
i , t
approximates
b
i , t
as the sample size increases.

Real or “true” heteroskedasticity is a property of the model error term. It leads to inefficiency but not bias and inconsistency. Misspecification, for instance by correlated omitted variables, leads to biased and inconsistent estimates, not simply inefficient ones and can generate “apparent” heteroskedasticity in the error term (see Thursby, 1982).

Taking logs is limited to positive data but closely related transforms such as the inverse hyperbolic sine function can be used to overcome this limitation, if it leads to well-specified models of the transformed data.
The long windows used in Easton, Harris, and Ohlson (1992) probably have this effect.
The pattern of misspecification of the time-series models does not change significantly if estimation uses the period 1955 to 2004.
Omission of a lag on book value as in Equation 11 further increases the number of flagged misspecification tests.
The standard error of the standard deviations of the coefficient over the 30 firms.
